title-group.article-title: Global modelling of fire protection performance of an intumescent coating under different furnace fire conditions

article-meta.aff: 1School of Mechanical, Aerospace and Civil Engineering, University of Manchester, Manchester, UK

author-notes.corresp: Yong C Wang, School of Mechanical, Aerospace and Civil Engineering, University of Manchester, Manchester M13 9PL, UK. Email: yong.wang@manchester.ac.uk

abstract.p: This article presents a method to model the overall fire protection performance of an intumescent coating under different post-flashover furnace fire conditions. Intumescent coatings are reactive fire protection materials, and their fire protection performance, among which the maximum expansion ratio is the key indicator, depends on the heating condition. The aim of this research is to find one common set of properties to enable the intumescent coating fire protection performance to be predicted across different heating conditions on the intumescent coating. The obtained properties are implemented in a model to predict the global expansion process of intumescent coating and the protected steel substrate temperature under various furnace temperature–time curves. This model has previously been demonstrated by the authors to provide accurate results for cone calorimeter tests under different levels of radiant heat flux (50 and 65 kW m−2) and with different combinations of steel plate thickness (5, 10 and 20 mm) and intumescent coating dry film thickness (0.4, 0.8 and 1.2 mm). This article will present the experimental results of post-flashover furnace fire tests under different fire temperature–time relationships (slow, fast and standard) for the same combinations of steel plate thickness and dry film thickness as used in the cone calorimeter tests. A comparison between the prediction and experimental results indicates that the steel plate temperature results are typically within 10% and the final expanded thickness within 20% of each other.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Fire retardant intumescent coatings are widely used as passive fire protection for structural steel. When exposed to fire, an intumescent coating undergoes several reactions to release gases and form chars as the temperature increases. The evolved gases cause the coating to bubble, foam and swell up to 100 times its original thickness to produce a porous charred thermal barrier to protect the substrate from rising in temperatures under fire attack.1,2

The fire performance of intumescent coatings is currently assessed based on the standard fire tests,3 in which steel members with intumescent coating are exposed to a fire with fixed, standard temperature–time relationship. The implicit assumption is that the thermal properties of intumescent coatings are independent of the fire condition. However, intumescent coatings are reactive and their thermal properties are strongly affected by the fire exposure condition,4,5 and consequently, it is not appropriate to treat intumescent coatings as a non-reactive fire protection material, and different fire scenarios have to be taken into consideration when assessing the fire protection performance of intumescent coatings. Clearly, it is not feasible to conduct infinite fire tests under different realistic fire exposure conditions in order to obtain the necessary thermal properties of intumescent coatings for each situation; therefore, it is necessary to develop a model that is capable of simulating the fire protection behaviour of intumescent coatings under different fires. It is important that this simulation model uses one consistent set of thermal properties that can be applied to different fire conditions.

Many mathematic and numerical models have been developed by different researchers.5–16 Among them, an approach first proposed by Cagliostro et al.6 has become increasingly popular. This method links the expansion process of intumescent coating with the chemical reactions and uses measurable global physical and chemical properties (e.g. reaction kinetics, mass and heat capacity) as modelling input parameters. However, a common problem with these models prevents them from wide applications, that is, the expansion ratio, one of the most important parameters for determining the fire protection performance of intumescent coating, is assumed to be a constant regardless of the heating condition. It has been well known that the expansion ratio of intumescent coating varies from a few to a hundred times the original thickness, and this value is influenced by the experimental conditions.6,7,17,18 In a proper predictive model, the expansion ratio should be a modelling output rather than an input.

In a previous article,19 the authors have proposed a model to predict the entire expansion process of intumescent coating and the protected steel substrate temperature under various cone calorimeter heating conditions. The framework of the model was based on the study by Di Blasi10 but instead of treating the expansion ratio as an input constant (as in Di Blasi), the authors’ method takes into account the effects of different heating conditions on the expansion process. All the input data necessary for the model are independent of the heating condition, so that the prediction model can be used for different fire conditions with one consistent set of thermal properties for each type of intumescent coating. These key thermal property parameter values may be obtained from thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and small-scale cone calorimeter tests. The modelling results were compared with the test results on samples heated by two different levels of cone calorimeter heat flux. Excellent agreement between the prediction and experimental results gives confidence in the feasibility of the proposed approach. The purpose of this article is to further validate the model by comparing the prediction results with furnace fire test results under different fire conditions.

sec.title: Theory and modelling
sec.p: The main purpose of this research is to investigate whether the authors’ model, applied to small-scale cone calorimeter tests,19 is also applicable to furnace tests under different fire conditions. Details of the model are presented in Ref. 19; here, only a summary of the important features and the authors’ new developments will be repeated.
The model considers a one-dimensional (1D) composite system consisting of a steel substrate and intumescent coating. The main assumptions are as follows:

list-item.p: The intumescent coating is made of three components: acid source (S1), blowing agent (S2) and charring materials (S3) with initial mass fractions of Y10Y20 and Y30, respectively. When exposed to heating, the three components follow three independent reactions corresponding to melting (equation (1)), swelling (equation (2)), and charring and degrading (equation (3))

The expansion of intumescent coating is mainly caused by the gases released from S2, and the expansion rate is governed by the ideal gas law (equation (4)). During the char degradation stage, the thickness of the intumescent char gradually shrinks due to oxidation. This thickness reduction is linearly related to the depletion of the charring materials. The reaction of S3 mainly occurs after the char has expanded. The porosity of an expanded char typically is more than 90%, and its density approaches that of air and does not change too much at the later stage of expansion. As a result, the volume of char is proportional to the mass of S3 and SC. Because only a unit area is considered in the model, it is sensible to assume that the thickness is proportional to the volume shrinkage

The expansion of intumescent coating only occurs within a temperature range between a lower value (Tmelt) and a higher value (TC). Tmelt is roughly the coating’s melting temperature. TC is the charring temperature, which is assumed to be the temperature at which the maximum driving force for expansion is reached. The driving force was mainly due to the gases released by S2 and can be expressed using the acceleration law (F=m2,g(∂2x/∂t2)). Applying this to equation (4) and neglecting the second derivatives, the following approximate relationship is obtained

Only part of the released gas of the blowing agent (G2) is trapped inside the intumescent coating to contribute to the expansion. β represents the trapped gas fraction of G2. At present, understanding of intumescent coating behaviour under heating is not sufficiently mature to allow an expression for β to be derived based on a sound scientific principle. Therefore, this research followed an intuitive and trial-and-error approach to find an expression for β. Initially, different fixed values of Tc were tried and different forms of β–T relationship (e.g. constant, triangular and exponential) were explored. But this process was not able to produce predictive results that were in ‘consistent’ agreement with test results for different heating conditions and different coating and steel plate thicknesses. The effects of variable coating temperature, mass (and via mass the rate of heating) should be included in the β–T relationship. After this exhaustive process, the following empirical relationship (equation (7)) was established
In equation (7), Ctrap is product specific and was found to be 1.0 for the type of intumescent coating studied by the authors.19

The expanded intumescent char is treated as a porous material with uniform distribution of spherical pores of the same size, and the thermal conductivity of the expanded intumescent char is dependent on the pore size (equation (28)). The mean pore size is proportional to the gas release of S2 ((1 −Y2)/Y2,0) and the remaining solid mass fraction during the oxidation process ((Y3+YC)/Y3,0). Although the bubble size is also affected by temperature, a bubble typically expands more than 10 times within a relatively narrow temperature range (473–723 K). Therefore, the sharp increase in bubble size is more a result of gases released than temperature, which increases about 1.5 times during the expansion phase. The pore size reaches the maximum (dmax) at the end of the expanding stage and gradually decreases during the charring stage (equation (8)), which is similar to the decrease in thickness in equation (5). Individual bubble behaviour and the change in bubble number are not considered in this model

sec.p: At the end of all reactions, the conversion of S2 and S3 are completed, so Y2 = 0, Y3 = 0 and YC = νc×Y3,0, substituting these in equation (8), the final bubble size df can be obtained
The initial bubble size is normally much smaller than the maximum bubble size, so equation (9) can be further simplified as
In the furnace tests (for details, see the next section), the test sample was surrounded by fire of temperature Tfire. In the simulation model, the boundary condition at the coating–fire interface is
At the intumescent coating–steel substrate interface, the boundary conditions are

If the steel plate was covered by intumescent coating of the same thickness on both sides, only half of the specimen may be modelled because of symmetry and the heat transfer condition at the plane of symmetry is

Unfortunately, for the authors’ tests, it was found that the intumescent coating thickness was different on both sides of the steel plate in many samples. Equation (15) is no longer applicable, and the entire coating/steel/coating assembly has to be simulated using the boundary conditions expressed in equations (11) to (14).
The heat transfer equation inside the steel is
Other equations are listed in Table 1. These equations were solved using the finite difference method, and the program was developed in MATLAB®. Table 2 lists the input parameter values.

caption.p: List of equations
Values of input parameters used in the model19

sec.title: Materials and sample preparation
sec.p: The substrates were 200 × 200-mm steel plates of three different thicknesses of 6, 10 and 20 mm. The intumescent coating used was FX100, a water-based product from Leighs Paints (Bolton, UK). The coating was applied by the supplier. Both sides of the steel plates were covered, and the target dry film thicknesses (DFTs) were 0.4, 0.8 and 1.2 mm on each side of the steel plate. Samples were thoroughly dried at ambient temperature. The DFTs were measured using a digital thickness gauge, and the measured DFTs are listed in Table 3.

caption.p: Steel thickness and DFT for all tests

fn.p: DFT: dry film thickness; ISO: International Organization for Standardization.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Sample ID = steel thickness (A: 6 mm, B: 10 mm, C: 20 mm) + target DFT (04, 08, 12 mm) + fire type (ISO – iso, SL – slow, FA – fast).

sec.title: Furnace test
sec.p: The tests were carried out in the furnace of the University of Manchester. This furnace measured 1.5 m × 1.5 m × 1.5 m in internal dimensions and was heated by a gas burner. The temperature field inside the furnace was measured by six bead thermocouples (TCs), and the average temperature of these six TCs was controlled to follow the specified fire temperature–time relationship. The same three fire temperature–time profiles as those used in Refs 16 and 20 were followed. Figure 1 shows the three fire temperature–time curves, referred to as International Organization for Standardization (ISO) fire (standard temperature–time curve according to ISO 834), fast fire and slow fire. The slow and fast temperature–time curves were calculated using the Eurocode 1 parametric fire equations,21 for a nominal room of 5 × 5 m2 in plan and 3 m in height, thermal inertia of 1160 J m−2 K−1 s−1/2, fire load of 510 MJ m−2 floor area with opening factor of 0.02 m−1/2 and fire load of 1700 MJ m−2 floor area with opening factor of 0.08 m−1/2, respectively. In each test, after heating for 1 h, the furnace was switched off and the sample cooled in furnace with extract fan switched on.

caption.p: Three fire profiles used in the furnace tests.
ISO: International Organization for Standardization.

sec.p: As shown in Figure 2(a), the edges of the samples were insulated by wrapping a layer of 20-mm mineral wool to prevent any edge effect. Figure 2(b) shows the positions of the TCs inside the steel plate. Each sample stood vertically on its edge with the help of a rest rod at the top. Figure 3 shows the arrangement of the test specimens inside the furnace. The furnace control TCs were placed near the samples to ensure that gas temperature near the samples was as close as possible to the recorded furnace temperature.

caption.p: (a) A sample insulated by mineral wool around all edges and (b) schematic of sample and TC locations.
TC: thermocouple.
(a) Vertical standing of samples inside the furnace and (b) schematic of furnace arrangement.
TC: thermocouple.

sec.title: Results and discussions
sec.p: The coatings on both sides of the steel plate were intended to have the same DFT. However, as shown in Table 3, there was considerable difference in DFTs on the two sides of the same plate in many cases.
Figure 4 compares the average measured furnace temperature–time relationships with their design counterparts, indicating that the furnace was able to follow the design curves very closely.

caption.p: Comparison between measured and design furnace temperature–time relationships.
ISO: International Organization for Standardization.

sec.title: ISO fire results
sec.p: Figure 5 shows typical appearance of samples after a standard fire test. The intumescent coating char was consistent and the bubbles appeared to be uniformly distributed. It was not possible to measure the bubble sizes accurately. Figure 5 shows a picture of sample B08ISO after ISO fire test, and the average bubble size appeared on the surface was about 2.5 mm, which is consistent with the value assumed in the modelling (equation (10), df≈dmax×νc = 3.5 × 0.65 = 2.3 mm).

caption.p: (a) A typical sample (B08ISO) after ISO fire test and (b) a close view of the bubbles formed on the surface.
ISO: International Organization for Standardization.

sec.p: Since the test specimens were inside the furnace, it was not possible to measure the expansion process, which was undertaken during the authors’ cone calorimeter tests.19 Therefore, only the final expansion ratios can be compared. The measured final expansion ratio was based on the sample taken out of the furnace after cooling down. The predicted expansion ratio was the value at the end of the heating period. Table 4 compares the predicted and measured final expansion ratios, separated for the two sides of each test specimen due to different DFTs. The final expansion ratio was clearly not constant as assumed in modelling by others (e.g. Refs 6, 7, 10, 11, 13, and 16–18). Within the context of this set of tests, the final expansion ratio was higher for faster steel temperature rise (thinner steel and/or thinner intumescent coating). The results in Table 4 show that the predictions gave the same range of expansion ratios as the measurements (about 20–40), and in most cases, the predicted expansion ratios were within 20% of the measurements. Bearing in mind the simplicity of the model (equation (8)), this level of accuracy may be considered acceptable. In fact, as far as the steel temperature is concerned, the intumescent coating thicknesses on both sides of the steel plate should be combined to give an equivalent coating thickness. This may be derived in the following.

caption.p: Comparison between measured and predicted final expansion ratios for the ISO fire tests (italic rows are for samples tested horizontally)

fn.p: DFT: dry film thickness; ISO: International Organization for Standardization.

fn.label: a
fn.p: MER: measured expansion ratio; PER: predicted expansion ratio; Error: (PER–MER)/MER.

fn.label: b
fn.p: EO = equivalent overall; EO error calculated from equation (35).

sec.p: The heat flux from side A to the steel plate is

in which λA is the thermal conductivity of the expanded intumescent char and xA is the expanded thickness. The coating surface temperature is assumed to be the same as the fire temperature Tf, which is an acceptable assumption because the amount of heat stored in the coating is very small.
Similarly on side B

At the same temperature, the thermal conductivity of the expanded intumescent char (not the effective thermal conductivity applied to the original thickness) may be assumed to be the same (equation (30)), which means λA = λB = λ.
Since it is the total heat flux into the steel plate that increases the steel temperature, then

The denominator in equation (34) is the equivalent thickness of the expanded char. A similar equation can be derived to give the equivalent DFT for the steel plate. Therefore, the equivalent overall expansion ratio for the intumescent coating with different DFTs and expansion ratios on both sides of the steel plate can be calculated using

Table 4 presents this value based on the measured intumescent coating thicknesses and the predicted intumescent coating thicknesses for all ISO tests. The difference between the predicted and measured values is less than 20% in the majority of the cases, which is considered acceptable.

As shown in Table 4, the values (in italic) are also the results for samples tested horizontally, which were used to assess the effects on sample orientation. In the prediction method, sample orientation would have no effect on the prediction results (cf. C12ISO2 and C12ISO3 with C12ISO1), but there were substantial differences in the experimental results. In fact, the DFTs on both sides of the samples were similar and any prediction method would have given similar results. However, in the tests, the coating on the bottom surface expanded more than two and three times the coating on the top surface of the two samples. This difference could not have been caused by intumescent coating dropping off under self-weight; otherwise, the expansion ratio of the coating on the bottom surface would have been lower, not higher, which was the measured value. The only other possible factor was the airflow within the furnace, particularly because the samples were near the exhaust of the furnace (see Figure 6). The effects of airflow and pressure were not included in the prediction model and neither would it be desirable to do so because of the impossibility of predicting fire gas pressure with any accuracy. Fortunately, the predictions of the equivalent expansion ratio (calculated using equation (34)) give much better accuracy, and it is the equivalent overall expansion ratio that mainly affects the accuracy of the predicted steel plate temperature.

caption.p: Horizontal set-up inside furnace.

sec.p: To substantiate the above claim, Figure 7(a) to (c) compares the recorded and predicted steel plate temperature–time relationships for all the tests under the ISO fire test condition. In general, the prediction results are close to the measured results. This is not surprising considering that the predicted and measured equivalent overall expansion ratios were in good agreement. To give an indication of the overall accuracy of the predicted steel plate temperatures, Figure 8 compares the predicted and measured steel plate temperatures for temperature levels of practical interest (400°C–750°C at 50°C interval) reached at the same time. Except for only a very few cases, the predicted and measured temperatures are within 10% of each other. The exception is sample A04ISO, which had a thin steel plate thickness combined with a thin intumescent coating thickness, for which the model tended to over-predict both the steel temperature and the expansion thickness. Fortunately, a combination of thin steel plate thickness and thin intumescent coating thickness is unlikely to appear in practice.

caption.p: Comparison between recorded and predicted steel temperature–time curves for ISO fire: (a–c) for samples with 6-, 10- and 20-mm steel plate thickness, respectively.
ISO: International Organization for Standardization.
Comparison between the predicted and measured steel plate temperatures for ISO fire test samples.
ISO: International Organization for Standardization.

sec.p: In one test (A08ISO, Figure 7(a)), the experimental and prediction results diverge at the later stage of the test (time > 2900 s) with the measured temperature being much higher than the predicted temperature. This was caused by cracks appearing in the intumescent char at very high temperatures. The prediction model is unable to predict intumescent char cracking. Fortunately, this would not be of practical concern because the intumescent char remained intact within the range of steel plate temperatures of practical interest.

sec.title: Slow fire tests
sec.p: As shown in Figure 9, the surface of intumescent coating after a slow fire test was typically black because the surface temperature was not sufficiently high to oxidize the carbon. Also, the bubbles appear to have larger sizes compared to those observed after the ISO tests. This is in agreement with the assumption that the bubble size reduces as the oxidation process progresses (equation (8)). Figure 9 indicates that the maximum bubble size is about 5 mm. This value is higher than the assumed maximum bubble size of 3.5 mm (Table 2). This assumed value alone would give a moderately lower value of the predicted thermal conductivity (equation (31)). Fortunately, for this fire condition, the predicted expansion ratios (Table 5) are slightly low, and this compensates for the slight under-prediction of the thermal conductivity of the expanded intumescent char. Notwithstanding this explanation, Table 5 shows that the predicted equivalent expansion ratio is within about 20% of the measured value for most tests.

caption.p: (a) Typical appearance (B08SL) after a slow fire test and (b) close view of bubbles.
Comparison between measured and predicted final expansion ratios for the slow fire tests

fn.label: a
fn.p: MER: measured expansion ratio; PER: predicted expansion ratio; Error: (PER–MER)/MER.

fn.label: b
fn.p: EO = equivalent overall; EO error calculated from equation (35).

sec.p: As expected, the predicted steel plate temperatures achieved much better accuracy than the predicted intumescent coating expansion ratio. Figure 10(a) to (c) compares the test and modelling steel plate temperature–time relationships. The agreement between these two sets of results is highly satisfactory.

caption.p: Comparison between recorded and predicted steel temperature–time curves for slow fire: (a–c) for samples with 6-, 10- and 20-mm steel plate thickness, respectively.
ISO: International Organization for Standardization.

sec.p: The worst predictions were for samples C08SL and C12SL, which represented the highly unlikely situation of thick steel plate with thick intumescent coating under a low temperature fire. For these samples, because the intumescent coatings were kept within the relative low temperature range (200°C–500°C) for a long period of time (>30 min), the intumescent coatings probably did not react fully. Comparing the pictures taken of these samples after the fire tests with those of a more practical combination of coating/steel thickness for the fire condition (C04SL) in Figure 11, the intumescent char of the former appeared to be denser and the bubbles formed were quite blurry (Figure 11(d)). The intumescent char of the former looked like layers of compact carbon blanket instead of the typical structure of sponge cake of fully reacted intumescent char (C04SL). Because the steel temperature was low, it would not be a cause of concern for steel structural safety. Nevertheless, it indicates that the prediction model may not be applicable to sustained low temperature fires such as smothering fires, suggesting that the effects of different smothering fire times on intumescent coating performance should be further investigated.

caption.p: Clockwise: (a) side view of samples C04SL and C08SL, (b) front view of C04SL, (c) front view of C08SL and (d) a close view of the char residual formed from C08SL.

sec.title: Fast fire tests
sec.p: Figure 12 shows that as a result of the high fire temperature, the intumescent coating experienced very high temperatures and completely reacted and oxidized, giving the white appearance with consistent bubble sizes. The predicted equivalent overall expansion ratios were within 20% of the measurements in all cases (Table 6). The predicted steel temperatures were slightly higher than the measured values in most cases, due to the assumption of constant bubble size (2.3 mm as calculated under the ISO fire test), while the actual bubble size (about 1.5 mm in Figure 12) for the fast fire case seemed to be smaller. Bearing in mind the observation of larger bubble size under the slow fire test than the assumed value, it seems that fire exposure condition also has some influence on the bubble size. Nevertheless, the accuracy of the predicted steel temperatures is only weakly affected by the inaccuracy in bubble size assumption.20 This is confirmed by the good agreement between the predicted and measured steel plate temperature–time relationships, as shown in Figure 13.

caption.p: Bubbles formed after fast fire tests (a) A04FA and (b) B04FA.
Comparison between measured and predicted final expansion ratios for the fast fire tests

fn.label: a
fn.p: MER: measured expansion ratio; PER: predicted expansion ratio; Error: (PER–MER)/MER.

fn.label: b
fn.p: EO = equivalent overall; EO error calculated from equation (35).

caption.p: Comparison between recorded and predicted steel temperature–time curves for fast fire: (a–c) for samples with 6-, 10- and 20-mm steel plate thickness, respectively.

sec.title: Summary and conclusions
sec.p: This article has used the experimental results of furnace fire tests on intumescent coating and protected steel plates to check the applicability of an intumescent coating model for applications under different fire conditions. This model predicts the expansion process of intumescent coating, the maximum expansion ratio, the shrinkage stage, and the steel plate temperature. Because the objective of the research is to assess the applicability of the model under any heating/fire condition by using only one set of input data, the model input parameters, including chemical kinetics values (obtainable from TGA tests), bubble size (assumed to be constant) and initial thermal properties (thermal conductivity, density and specific heat of the initial unexpanded coating), were the same as used for a separate cone calorimeter study previously performed by the authors.19 The fire tests covered three steel plate thicknesses (6, 10 and 20 mm), three nominal coating DFTs (0.4, 0.8 and 1.2 mm) and three fire conditions (fast, slow and ISO). The following conclusions may be drawn:

list-item.p: The proposed model was able to produce accurate results. The predicted maximum expansion ratio was within 20% of the measured value in the majority of the cases (Figure 14). The predicted steel plate temperature was within 10% of the test results in most cases (Figure 15). The model was able to predict the full range of intumescent coating expansion ratios. This comparison gives increased confidence in the proposed expansion model (equation (7)).

Under the same fire condition, the expansion of the intumescent coating was significantly different for different values of the steel plate thickness and intumescent coating DFTs. This confirms that the current intumescent coating assessment method, based on one unique thermal conductivity–temperature relationship regardless of the steel plate and intumescent coating thicknesses, is not correct. This was expected by the authors before this research and has been confirmed by the results of this research.

Within the parameters examined in this research, fast fire exposure and high coating temperature appeared to enable the intumescent coating to undergo complete reaction to produce the desired expanded intumescent char protection. Slow fire exposure and low coating temperature did not seem to be able to allow the intumescent coating to react fully to form the desired char. However, because the steel temperature involved will be low, this is unlikely to have important practical implications on steel structure safety under post-flashover condition. Nevertheless, the ability of the intumescent coating to expand fully after prolonged period of smothering fire should be carefully examined.

In the prediction model, the maximum bubble size, which is used to calculate the thermal conductivity of the expanded intumescent char, does not appear to be a constant value (assumed to be 3.5 mm for this particular product), but tended to be higher (about 5 mm) for the slow fire tests and lower (about 2.5 mm) for the fast fire tests. However, even with such a range of bubble size, the assumption of a constant value generates only moderate inaccuracy in the predicted steel temperature. Such an assumption vastly simplifies the modelling process.

caption.p: Comparison between predicted and measured overall expansion ratios for all samples.
Comparison between predicted and measured steel plate temperatures for all samples.

sec.title: Nomenclature
sec.p: a Unit surface area (m2)
d Bubble size (m)
e Emissivity
h Convection heat transfer coefficient (W m−2)
m Mass (kg)
n Number of modelling layers in the coating
t Time (s)
x Coordinate along coating thickness (m)
y Coordinate along steel thickness (m)
A Pre-exponential factor (s−1)
C Specific heat capacity (J K−1 kg−1)
Ctrap Trapped gas coefficient
E Activation energy (kJ mol−1)
H Heat of pyrolysis per unit mass of material (J kg−1)
K Reaction rate constant
Po Gas pressure (Pa)
Q Heat flux (kW m−2)
R Universal gas constant (J mol−1 K−1)

S
1
→
K
1
G
1
Mass flow rate of gas per unit area (kg s−1 m−2)
T Temperature (K)
Wg Mean gas molecular weight (kg mol−1)
Y Mass fraction

sec.title: Greek letters
sec.p: β Proportion of gas released by the blowing agent that is retained to cause expansion
Δt Time step (s)
Δx Thickness of coating element layer (m)
Δy Thickness of steel element layer (m)
ΔH Decomposition heat in an element layer
ε Void fraction
λ Thermal conductivity (W m−1 K−1)
ρ Density (kg m−3)
σ Stefan–Boltzmann constant (W m−2 K−4)
ν Conversion rate

sec.title: Subscripts
sec.p: c Coating
g Gas
s Solid
A A side coating
B B side coating
C Char
G1, G2 and G3 Gas products from S1, S2 and S3, respectively
S Steel
S1, S2 and S3 Reactive components
1, 2 and 3 Intumescent coating components

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Yong Zhang is a Research Associate and has PhD degree. Research interest include material sciences.

Yong C Wang has a PhD degree, Fellow of Institution of Structural Engineers, UK, and Professor of Structural and Fire Engineering. Research interests includes fire protection materials and structural engineering.

Colin G Bailey has a PhD degree, Fellow of Institution of Civil Engineers and Institution of Structural Engineers, UK, Vice-President, Dean of Faculty of Engineering and Physical Sciences, Professor of Structural Engineering. Research interests includes fire engineering and structural engineering.
Andrew P Taylor has a PhD degree, Head of Sciences, Leighspaints.
